title: Figurative Language — Simile and Metaphor
description: Students learn to identify and use similes (comparisons using like or as) and metaphors (direct comparisons without like or as). They find examples in literature and write their own.
instructions:
1. Ask: 'What does it mean when someone says he ran like the wind? Did he actually become wind? No — it is a comparison!'
2. Introduce SIMILE: a comparison using 'like' or 'as.' 'She was as brave as a lion.' 'The stars twinkled like diamonds.'
3. Introduce METAPHOR: a comparison WITHOUT like or as. 'He is a rock.' 'Life is a journey.' The thing IS the other thing.
4. Compare: simile says something is LIKE something else. Metaphor says it IS something else.
5. Find examples in read-aloud books from previous weeks.
6. Simile and metaphor sorting activity: classify 15 sentences.
7. Students write 5 similes and 5 metaphors in their journals.
materials_needed: Sorting cards with similes and metaphors

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 15 sentence cards: 7-8 similes and 7-8 metaphors for sorting. Mark simile and metaphor examples in previously read books.

slides.text: 'When a writer says The warrior was as fierce as a lion, did the warrior literally become a lion? No! The writer is making a COMPARISON to help us picture how fierce the warrior was. This special comparison is called a SIMILE. Similes use the words LIKE or AS. Listen for those signal words!'

'Now what if the writer says The warrior WAS a lion in battle? No like or as — just IS. This is a METAPHOR. The writer says the warrior IS a lion to create an even stronger image. Both similes and metaphors paint pictures in the reader's mind, but metaphors are more direct and powerful.' Write examples of each on the board.

'Let us find the clue: does it have LIKE or AS? Then it is a SIMILE. Is it a direct comparison without those words? Then it is a METAPHOR. The classroom was a zoo (metaphor). The classroom was like a zoo (simile). The meaning is similar, but the form is different.' Practice with 5 examples together.

slides.prompt: Sort the 15 sentence cards into similes and metaphors. Then write 5 original similes and 5 original metaphors in your journal. Try to make them vivid and creative! Example simile: 'The Aegean Sea sparkled like a field of sapphires.' Example metaphor: 'Athens was the brain of Greece.'

slides.text: Similes and metaphors are tools that make writing come alive. They paint pictures in the reader's mind. Similes compare using like or as. Metaphors compare directly. Look for them in everything you read this week — once you know what they are, you will see them everywhere!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between similes and metaphors and write original examples of each?

parent_notes: Figurative language is a major reading comprehension skill and a powerful writing tool. Once children learn to recognize similes and metaphors, they find them everywhere — in books, songs, conversations, and advertisements. Encourage your child to collect favorites in a special section of their journal. Song lyrics are full of figurative language and make great practice material.

title: Measurement — Mass: Grams and Kilograms
description: Students learn to measure mass (how heavy something is) using metric units: grams and kilograms. They use a balance scale to weigh objects and understand the relationship 1 kg = 1,000 g.
instructions:
1. Distinguish mass from weight: mass is the amount of matter in an object (does not change); weight is the pull of gravity (changes on the moon). For everyday purposes, we use them similarly.
2. Units: the gram (g) is the basic unit. A paperclip weighs about 1 gram.
3. A kilogram (kg) = 1,000 grams. A liter of water weighs 1 kg. A textbook weighs about 1 kg.
4. Demonstrate the balance scale: place object on one side, known weights on the other. When balanced, the mass is equal.
5. Students weigh 8-10 objects: estimate first, then weigh.
6. Classify objects: would you measure this in grams or kilograms?
7. Practice conversion: 3 kg = 3,000 g; 5,500 g = 5.5 kg.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the balance scale. Gather 8-10 objects of varying masses. Have known weights organized by size. Prepare a recording chart.

slides.text: 'We measured LENGTH in centimeters and meters. Now we measure MASS — how much matter is in an object, or how heavy it is. The basic unit is the GRAM. How heavy is 1 gram? About the same as a paperclip!' Hold up a paperclip. 'Very light! For heavier things, we use KILOGRAMS: 1 kilogram = 1,000 grams.'

'A kilogram is about as heavy as a liter bottle of water.' Hold one up. 'Or about as heavy as a thick textbook. YOUR body mass is measured in kilograms — most children your age have a mass of about 20-30 kg. An elephant is about 5,000 kg! A mouse is about 20 grams.'

Demonstrate the balance scale: 'Place the object on one side. Add weights to the other side until the scale balances. Then add up the weights — that is the object's mass!' Weigh an apple together: add 100g, 50g, 20g, 10g... it balances at about 180g. 'The apple has a mass of about 180 grams.'

slides.prompt: Weigh 8 objects: estimate the mass first, then use the balance scale to find the actual mass. Record in your chart. Then answer: Which is heavier, 2 kg or 1,500 g? Convert to the same unit to check! Solve: A bag of flour is 2 kg. You use 750 g. How much is left?

slides.text: Mass tells us how much matter is in an object. We measure in grams (small objects) and kilograms (heavy objects). 1 kg = 1,000 g. A paperclip is about 1 g, a liter of water is about 1 kg. Conversion works just like length: multiply to go from kg to g, divide to go from g to kg.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use a balance scale to measure mass and convert between grams and kilograms?

parent_notes: A balance scale is ideal for teaching mass because it makes the concept concrete. If you do not have one, a kitchen scale works well too. Cooking is a perfect context for practicing mass measurement — recipes use grams frequently. Benchmarks are key: 1 gram = paperclip, 100 grams = apple (roughly), 1 kilogram = liter of water. The kg-to-g conversion follows the same pattern as km-to-m (x1000).

title: Ancient Greece — The Philosophers: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle
description: Students learn about the three great Greek philosophers and their contributions to thinking and learning. They explore the Socratic method, Plato's Academy, and Aristotle's scientific observations.
instructions:
1. What is philosophy? Love of wisdom (philo = love, sophia = wisdom).
2. SOCRATES: asked questions instead of giving answers. The Socratic method: teaching by asking 'Why?' over and over. He believed 'The unexamined life is not worth living.'
3. PLATO: Socrates's student. Started the Academy (one of the first schools!). Wrote dialogues. Believed in ideal forms.
4. ARISTOTLE: Plato's student. Studied EVERYTHING: science, politics, logic, animals, ethics. Tutor to Alexander the Great.
5. These three are like a chain: Socrates taught Plato, Plato taught Aristotle.
6. Practice the Socratic method: ask 'Why?' 5 times about a simple statement.
7. Students write a brief biography of one philosopher.
materials_needed: Images or busts of Socrates, Plato, Aristotle

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of the three philosophers. Place them on the timeline. Have a simple biography reference available for each.

slides.text: 'Greece gave us something even more important than buildings or art — it gave us PHILOSOPHY: the love of wisdom. Philo means love, sophia means wisdom. Philosophers ask the biggest questions: What is truth? What is goodness? How should we live? Today we meet three of the greatest thinkers in history.'

'SOCRATES taught by asking questions. Instead of telling his students the answer, he would ask Why? over and over until they figured it out themselves. He said: The only true wisdom is knowing that you know nothing. He never wrote anything down! His student PLATO wrote down his ideas and started the ACADEMY — one of the first schools in history.'

'ARISTOTLE was Plato's best student, but he went even further. He studied EVERYTHING: animals, plants, stars, government, logic, poetry, weather. He was the first person to organize knowledge into categories. And he became the tutor of a young prince named Alexander — who would become Alexander the Great! Socrates taught Plato, Plato taught Aristotle — a chain of genius.'

slides.prompt: First, practice the Socratic method: start with 'It is important to learn.' Ask 'Why?' Answer, then ask 'Why?' again. Keep going 5 times. Then choose one philosopher and write a short biography: when they lived, what they believed, what they are famous for, and why they matter today.

slides.text: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle created the foundations of Western thought. Socrates taught us to question everything. Plato showed us the power of ideas. Aristotle showed us how to observe and organize knowledge. Their ideas, from 2,400 years ago, still shape how we think, learn, and govern today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three Greek philosophers, describe their key ideas, and explain the teacher-student chain?

parent_notes: Philosophy for children is about teaching thinking skills. The Socratic method — asking 'Why?' repeatedly — is a powerful dinner table activity. Children love asking 'why?' anyway! The teacher-student chain (Socrates to Plato to Aristotle) is an easy mnemonic: S-P-A (SPA). Aristotle's broad interests connect to the Montessori philosophy of the interconnectedness of knowledge. Ask your child: 'What big questions would you like to answer?'

title: Europe — Countries, Capitals, and Major Features
description: Students explore the continent of Europe: its major countries, capital cities, mountain ranges, rivers, and the European Union. They compare Europe's size and diversity to other continents studied.
instructions:
1. Show Europe on the globe and world map. It shares a landmass with Asia (Eurasia).
2. Europe is the second-smallest continent but has many countries (~50!).
3. Major countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, United Kingdom, Greece, and others.
4. Major features: Alps mountains, Rhine River, Danube River, English Channel, Scandinavian Peninsula.
5. Briefly introduce the European Union (EU): a partnership of countries that cooperate economically.
6. Fun fact: many European countries are smaller than US states!
7. Students label a map of Europe with at least 10 countries, 5 capitals, and 3 physical features.

items: Political and physical maps of Europe
slides.setup_instructions: Print blank outline maps of Europe. Display both political and physical reference maps. Have the atlas available for students to look up countries and capitals.

slides.text: 'Today we zoom out from Greece to look at the whole continent of EUROPE! Find it on the globe. Europe is actually connected to Asia — together they form EURASIA. Europe is the second-smallest continent, but it has about 50 countries packed into it! That is a LOT of different cultures, languages, and traditions.'

'Here are some major countries.' Point to each on the map. 'France — capital Paris, the Eiffel Tower! Germany — capital Berlin. Italy — shaped like a boot, capital Rome. Spain — capital Madrid. The United Kingdom — London. And of course Greece — Athens. Each of these countries has its own language, food, and culture.'

'Physical features: the ALPS are Europe's highest mountains, running through France, Switzerland, Italy, and Austria. The RHINE and DANUBE are two great rivers. The ENGLISH CHANNEL separates Britain from France. And many European countries work together in the EUROPEAN UNION — they share a currency called the euro and cooperate on trade and laws.'

slides.prompt: On your blank map of Europe: (1) Color and label at least 10 countries. (2) Mark and label 5 capital cities with stars. (3) Label the Alps, Rhine River, Danube River, Mediterranean Sea, and Atlantic Ocean. (4) Draw a small symbol for each country's famous landmark if you know one!

slides.text: Europe may be small, but it is incredibly diverse — 50 countries, dozens of languages, and centuries of history packed into a continent smaller than some individual countries! We have already studied one European civilization in depth: Greece. In a few weeks, we will study Rome, another European powerhouse that changed the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student locate and name at least 10 European countries, 5 capitals, and major physical features?

parent_notes: Europe geography connects directly to the history being studied. Consider using puzzle maps (Montessori-style) if available. The sheer number of countries makes Europe interesting but challenging. Focus on the major countries first and expand gradually. Food is a great connector: French crepes, Italian pasta, Spanish paella, British fish and chips, German pretzels. Plan a European food night!

title: Read Aloud — Greek Myth: Athena and Arachne
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Athena and Arachne, exploring themes of pride, talent, and the dangers of boasting. Students connect to the invertebrate unit (spiders/arachnids).
instructions:
1. Connect to science: 'Remember arachnids? Where does that word come from? Today we find out!'
2. Set context: Arachne was a mortal woman who wove the most beautiful tapestries.
3. Read the myth: Arachne boasted she was better than Athena. They had a weaving contest.
4. Arachne's tapestry was perfect — but it insulted the gods. Athena destroyed it and turned Arachne into a spider.
5. Discuss: Was Arachne talented? Yes! Was she wise? No — her pride angered a goddess.
6. Etymology: Arachne's name gives us 'arachnid' — the scientific name for spiders!
7. Students write about the theme and draw Arachne weaving.
materials_needed: Greek mythology book with Athena and Arachne

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate version of the Athena and Arachne myth. Preview for discussion points.

slides.text: 'Remember when we studied arachnids — spiders? I promised you would find out where that word comes from. Today's myth explains it! It is the story of a woman named ARACHNE who was the greatest weaver in all of Greece. But she made a terrible mistake...'

Read the myth aloud. Pause at key moments: 'Arachne says she can weave better than Athena — the goddess of crafts! Would you dare challenge a goddess?' Build to the weaving contest and its dramatic conclusion.

After reading: 'Was Arachne talented? Absolutely — her weaving was perfect! But was she wise? She boasted and insulted the gods. This is hubris again — like Icarus. And now you know: spiders are called ARACHNIDS because of this myth. Arachne was turned into a spider, doomed to weave forever!'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Draw Arachne at her loom, weaving her beautiful tapestry. (2) Write the lesson/moral of this myth. (3) Answer: How does this myth connect to our science lessons about arachnids? (4) Compare Arachne's hubris to Icarus's hubris — how are they similar?

slides.text: Greek myths often warn against hubris — believing you are better than the gods. Arachne had extraordinary talent, but her pride was her downfall. Her name lives on in science: arachnid. This is cross-curricular learning at its best: mythology, science, and language all connected!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Arachne myth, explain the word origin of 'arachnid,' and identify the theme of hubris?

parent_notes: This myth brilliantly connects to the science unit on arachnids. The word etymology (arachnid from Arachne) demonstrates how mythology lives on in our language. The theme of hubris recurs in Greek mythology — compare to Icarus from last week. Discuss with your child: is there a difference between being proud of your work and being boastful? How can we celebrate talent without hubris?

title: Figurative Language — Personification
description: Students learn about personification: giving human qualities to non-human things. They identify personification in literature and everyday language and write sentences using this technique.
instructions:
1. Review simile and metaphor from Day 1.
2. Introduce PERSONIFICATION: giving human qualities to animals, objects, or ideas.
3. Examples: 'The wind whispered through the trees.' (Wind cannot whisper.) 'The sun smiled down on us.' (Sun cannot smile.) 'Time flies.' (Time has no wings.)
4. Discuss: personification makes writing more vivid and emotional. It helps us connect to non-human things.
5. Find personification in familiar texts and songs.
6. Game: take an object and give it 3 human qualities (the angry volcano, the lazy river, the dancing leaves).
7. Students write 8 personification sentences and illustrate their favorite one.
materials_needed: Object cards for the personification game

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare object cards (sun, wind, ocean, clock, stars, moon, river, mountain, fire, shadow). Mark examples of personification in previously read books.

slides.text: 'We know similes and metaphors. Today: PERSONIFICATION! This is when we give HUMAN qualities to non-human things. The wind does not really whisper — but when we say The wind whispered, we can almost HEAR it, can we not? We are treating the wind as if it were a person.'

'Listen for the human action in each example: The sun SMILED down on the village. Lightning DANCED across the sky. The flowers NODDED their heads. The ocean ROARED with anger. Can the sun really smile? Can flowers nod? No! But personification helps us FEEL the world around us as if nature were alive.'

'You actually use personification all the time without knowing it! Have you ever said My computer is being stubborn or The alarm clock screamed at me? Those are personification! Let us play a game: I will hold up an object card, and you give it a human quality.' Practice with sun, wind, ocean, clock.

slides.prompt: Write 8 personification sentences. Give human qualities to: the moon, the ocean, a mountain, time, a river, the wind, a shadow, and one object of your choice. Then choose your most vivid sentence and illustrate it literally — draw the object doing the human action!

slides.text: Personification brings the non-human world to life through language. When we say the wind whispered or the sun smiled, we help readers FEEL a connection to nature. You now know THREE types of figurative language: simile, metaphor, and personification. These are the tools that make writing magical!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write personification, distinguishing it from simile and metaphor?

parent_notes: Personification is everywhere in everyday language: 'the car died,' 'my stomach is telling me,' 'the alarm screamed.' Help your child notice these expressions in conversation and books. The illustration activity (drawing a mountain literally marching or a clock literally running) creates memorable, often humorous images that cement the concept. Personification is also common in poetry — revisit some poems from last week to find examples.

title: Measurement — Capacity: Liters and Milliliters
description: Students learn to measure liquid capacity using liters (L) and milliliters (mL). They practice pouring, measuring with graduated cylinders, and understanding the relationship 1 L = 1,000 mL.
instructions:
1. Capacity: how much liquid a container can hold.
2. The liter (L): a common water bottle is 1 liter. Show one.
3. The milliliter (mL): a very small amount. 1 L = 1,000 mL. A teaspoon is about 5 mL.
4. Show measuring tools: measuring cups, graduated cylinders, marked pitchers.
5. Demonstrate reading a graduated cylinder: read at the bottom of the meniscus (curved surface).
6. Hands-on: pour water into containers and measure the volume.
7. Estimate and measure the capacity of various containers.
8. Conversion practice: 2 L = 2,000 mL; 3,500 mL = 3.5 L.
materials_needed: Graduated cylinders or measuring cups (mL and L)

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a water measurement station with towels to catch spills. Have containers of various sizes ready. Fill a large pitcher with water for pouring.

slides.text: 'We measured length and mass. Now we measure CAPACITY — how much liquid a container holds. The basic unit is the LITER.' Hold up a liter bottle. 'This is 1 liter. For smaller amounts, we use MILLILITERS. Milli means thousand, so 1 liter = 1,000 milliliters. A teaspoon is about 5 mL. A small medicine cup is about 30 mL.'

'To measure liquids, we use these tools.' Show graduated cylinder, measuring cups. 'Pour the liquid in and read the level. Important: read at the BOTTOM of the curved surface — this curve is called the meniscus. Always place the measuring tool on a flat surface and look at it at eye level.'

'Let us practice! How much does this cup hold? Estimate first: I think about 250 mL. Now pour water in, measure, and check.' Demonstrate with 2-3 containers. 'Remember: 1,000 mL = 1 L. So 250 mL is one-quarter of a liter, or 0.25 L.' Connect to fractions and decimals.

slides.prompt: Estimate and then measure the capacity of 6 containers. Record your estimate and actual measurement in mL. Convert each to liters. Then solve: A recipe calls for 750 mL of water. You have a 1 L bottle. How much water is left after pouring? If you need to double the recipe, how many mL total?

slides.text: Capacity tells us how much liquid a container holds. We measure in liters (big amounts) and milliliters (small amounts). 1 L = 1,000 mL. Benchmarks: a water bottle is about 500 mL to 1 L, a teaspoon is about 5 mL, a bathtub is about 300 L. You now know three types of metric measurement: length, mass, AND capacity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student measure liquid capacity in mL and L, read a graduated cylinder, and convert between units?

parent_notes: Measuring capacity is naturally fun because it involves water and pouring. Cooking is the perfect real-world practice: recipes constantly use mL and L. Let your child measure ingredients for cooking. The connection to decimals and fractions is natural: 500 mL = 0.5 L = half a liter. The meniscus (curved water surface) is a good science observation too. Have towels ready — spills are part of learning!

title: Earth Science — Rocks and Minerals: The Three Types
description: Students begin earth science by learning about the three types of rocks: igneous (from fire/volcanoes), sedimentary (from layers of sediment), and metamorphic (changed by heat and pressure). They examine rock samples.
instructions:
1. Transition from living science to earth science: 'We studied animals. Now we study the Earth itself!'
2. What are rocks made of? Minerals — natural, non-living substances.
3. Three types of rocks:
   - IGNEOUS: formed from cooled lava/magma. Examples: granite, obsidian, basalt. 'Born from fire!'
   - SEDIMENTARY: formed from layers of sand, mud, shells compressed over millions of years. Examples: sandstone, limestone, shale.
   - METAMORPHIC: existing rocks changed by extreme heat and pressure. Examples: marble (from limestone), slate (from shale).
4. The rock cycle: rocks can change from one type to another over millions of years.
5. Examine rock samples with magnifying glasses.
6. Students create a rock cycle diagram.
materials_needed: Drawing paper for rock cycle diagram

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange rock samples by type. If real samples are unavailable, print high-quality images. Have magnifying glasses ready. Display a rock cycle poster.

slides.text: 'We have studied living things — animals and plants. Now we study the EARTH itself, starting with ROCKS! Rocks are everywhere: mountains, cliffs, riverbeds, even the ground beneath our feet. But not all rocks are the same. There are THREE main types, and each one forms in a different way.'

'Type 1: IGNEOUS rocks form when hot melted rock (magma or lava) cools and hardens. Igneous means born from fire! When a volcano erupts, the lava cools and becomes rock. Granite, obsidian (volcanic glass), and basalt are all igneous.' Show samples. 'Type 2: SEDIMENTARY rocks form when layers of sand, mud, and shells pile up and get pressed together over millions of years. Sandstone, limestone, and shale are sedimentary. Fossils are found in these rocks!'

'Type 3: METAMORPHIC rocks start as one type but get CHANGED by extreme heat and pressure deep underground. Meta means change, morph means form. Limestone gets squeezed and heated into MARBLE. Shale becomes SLATE. The Parthenon in Athens was built from marble — a metamorphic rock! And these three types connect in a ROCK CYCLE: any rock can become any other type over millions of years.'

slides.prompt: Examine the rock samples with a magnifying glass. Classify each as igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic. Record your observations (color, texture, crystals, layers). Then draw the ROCK CYCLE: show how igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks can transform into each other. Label the processes: melting, cooling, weathering, compacting, heat and pressure.

slides.text: The three rock types tell the story of how the Earth works: volcanoes create igneous rock, erosion and time create sedimentary rock, and the immense forces underground create metamorphic rock. Rocks that look solid and permanent are actually always changing — just very, very slowly!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three rock types, explain how each forms, and give examples of each?

parent_notes: Rock collecting is a wonderful hobby for children. Start a collection by finding rocks in your area and classifying them. Rock and mineral kits are available from educational suppliers and make this unit come alive. The rock cycle connects to many concepts: volcanoes, erosion, plate tectonics. The Parthenon being made of marble (metamorphic rock) connects nicely to the Greek history unit.

title: European Folk Music — Instruments and Traditions
description: Students explore the diverse folk music traditions of Europe, learning about instruments like the fiddle, accordion, bagpipes, and flamenco guitar. They listen to music from several European countries and compare styles.
instructions:
1. Europe has incredibly diverse music traditions — every country has its own folk music!
2. Listen to examples from 4-5 countries:
   - Ireland: fiddle and tin whistle (jigs and reels)
   - Spain: flamenco guitar and clapping
   - Scotland: bagpipes
   - Germany/Austria: accordion and yodeling
   - Greece: bouzouki and sirtaki dance music
3. Discuss: how does each style make you FEEL? Fast or slow? Happy or melancholy?
4. Identify common instruments: fiddle (violin played folk-style), accordion, bagpipes, guitar.
5. Try clapping along to different rhythms.
6. Students draw their favorite instrument and write about the music they liked best.
materials_needed: Audio recordings of European folk music (5 countries)

slides.setup_instructions: Queue up 5 recordings (2-3 minutes each) from Ireland, Spain, Scotland, Germany, and Greece. Display instrument images and point to each country on the map as its music plays.

slides.text: 'Europe has some of the most diverse and beautiful folk music in the world. Every country — sometimes every region within a country — has its own unique style. Today we take a musical tour of Europe!' Point to each country on the map as you introduce its music.

Play each recording, one at a time. 'This is Irish music — hear the fast fiddle and tin whistle? People dance jigs to this! Now Spain — flamenco has passionate guitar, hand clapping, and rhythmic stomping. Scotland — the BAGPIPES! Made from a bag that pushes air through pipes. Germany — the accordion, often with yodeling! And Greece — the bouzouki, with the famous sirtaki dance.'

'How does each style make you FEEL? Irish jigs might make you want to dance. Flamenco might feel fiery and passionate. Bagpipes might sound powerful and stirring. Music reflects the spirit of a culture. Let us clap along to each rhythm.' Practice clapping different rhythms.

slides.prompt: Draw your favorite European folk instrument in detail. Write: what country is it from, what does it sound like (use descriptive words), and how did the music make you feel? Then rank the 5 music styles from your most to least favorite and explain why.

slides.text: European folk music shows how the same basic human desire to make music leads to incredibly different results depending on culture and geography. Irish jigs, Spanish flamenco, Scottish bagpipes, German polkas, and Greek dance music are all expressions of joy, sorrow, celebration, and tradition.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify folk music styles and instruments from at least 3 European countries?

parent_notes: Music is one of the best windows into a culture. After this lesson, explore more European folk music on YouTube or streaming services. Many children develop strong preferences and want to learn more about specific traditions. If you can attend a folk music performance or festival, the experience is unforgettable. Playing recordings during dinner and asking 'What country do you think this is from?' extends the learning.

title: Care of the Environment — Plant Care and Gardening
description: Students learn to care for indoor plants and prepare a simple container garden. They practice watering techniques, soil preparation, and seed planting, connecting to botany knowledge.
instructions:
1. Connect to botany: 'We studied plants — roots, stems, leaves, flowers. Now we GROW them!'
2. Discuss what plants need: sunlight, water, soil (nutrients), air, space.
3. Demonstrate proper watering: check soil moisture first (stick finger in soil), water at the base not on leaves, do not overwater.
4. Prepare containers: add drainage material (pebbles), potting soil, create a small hole.
5. Plant seeds or seedlings: cover seeds lightly, press soil gently, water.
6. Label plants with name and planting date.
7. Create a care schedule: how often to water, where to place for sunlight.
8. Clean up the workspace.
materials_needed: Seeds (fast-growing: beans, herbs, marigolds) or seedlings

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace with newspaper. Pre-fill a tray with potting soil. Have pots, pebbles, seeds, and watering can arranged neatly.

slides.text: 'We studied plants in science — now we get to GROW them! Caring for plants teaches patience, responsibility, and observation. Remember what plants need: water, sunlight, soil with nutrients, and air. Today we will plant seeds and learn how to care for them.'

'First: prepare the pot. Add a layer of small pebbles at the bottom for drainage — this lets extra water escape so the roots do not drown. Then fill with potting soil, leaving about an inch at the top.' Demonstrate. 'Now make a small hole with your finger, drop in 2-3 seeds, and cover lightly with soil. Press gently. Water carefully — not too much!'

'Caring for plants is an ongoing responsibility. Check the soil every day: if the top feels dry, water it. Place your plant near a window for sunlight. Talk to your plant — some people believe it helps! Label your pot with the plant name and today's date, so you can track how long it takes to sprout.'

slides.prompt: Plant your own container garden: prepare the pot with drainage and soil, plant your seeds, water carefully, and label. Create a care schedule card: plant name, light needs, watering frequency, expected sprout time. Set up your plant in a good location and clean up your workspace completely.

slides.text: You are now responsible for a living thing! Check your plant daily, water when needed, and observe any changes. Keep a growth journal — measure and sketch your plant each week. Gardening teaches us that good things take time, care, and patience.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student properly plant seeds, describe plant care requirements, and create a care schedule?

parent_notes: Gardening is one of the most rewarding practical life activities. Fast-growing plants like beans or radishes show results within a week, maintaining motivation. Herbs (basil, cilantro, parsley) are practical because the child can eventually use them in cooking. Keep a growth journal — measuring the plant weekly connects to math measurement skills. This activity teaches responsibility, patience, and nurturing — core Montessori values.

title: Figurative Language — Reading Comprehension with Figurative Language
description: Students practice identifying and interpreting all three types of figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification) in the context of real passages. They determine literal vs. figurative meaning.
instructions:
1. Review all three types: simile (like/as), metaphor (is), personification (human qualities to non-human).
2. Read a short passage together. Stop at each figurative language example.
3. For each example: identify the type, explain what it literally says vs. what it actually means.
4. Discuss: why did the author choose figurative language instead of literal? What effect does it create?
5. Practice with 3 passages, increasing independence.
6. Students highlight/circle figurative language in a passage and label each instance.
7. Rewrite figurative sentences in literal language and compare the effect.
materials_needed: Highlighters (3 colors: one for each type)

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 3 short passages rich in figurative language. Print copies for highlighting. Create a color code: yellow = simile, blue = metaphor, green = personification.

slides.text: 'This week we learned similes, metaphors, and personification. Today we practice FINDING them in real reading passages. Good readers notice figurative language because it is key to understanding what an author really means. The wind howled does not mean the wind is literally a wolf!'

Read the first passage together. Stop at each figurative expression. 'Her smile was as warm as sunshine — what type? Simile! What does it mean literally? Her smile made people feel good, like standing in warm sunlight. Why did the author write it this way instead of just saying She had a nice smile? Because the simile creates a FEELING.'

'Let us try something interesting: rewrite figurative language as literal language. The mountain stood guard over the valley becomes The mountain was next to the valley. Which one paints a better picture? The figurative version! That is WHY authors use figurative language — to make writing vivid and memorable.'

slides.prompt: Read the passages and highlight figurative language in 3 colors: yellow = simile, blue = metaphor, green = personification. Label each example. Then choose 3 figurative sentences and rewrite them in literal language. Compare: which version is more interesting? Write a short paragraph explaining why authors use figurative language.

slides.text: Figurative language is a powerful reading comprehension tool. When you read the mountain stood guard, you understand more than just location — you understand that the mountain feels protective and strong. From now on, look for figurative language in everything you read. It will deepen your understanding and make you a better writer too!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify similes, metaphors, and personification in context and explain their literal vs. figurative meanings?

parent_notes: Figurative language comprehension is a critical reading skill tested on standardized assessments. More importantly, it deepens understanding and appreciation of literature. After this lesson, when you read together, pause occasionally and ask: 'Is the author being literal or figurative? What does that really mean?' This develops analytical reading habits that will serve your child throughout their education.

title: Measurement — Comparing and Converting Mass and Capacity
description: Students practice converting between grams/kilograms and milliliters/liters, and solve comparison and word problems involving both types of measurement.
instructions:
1. Review: 1 kg = 1,000 g, 1 L = 1,000 mL. Both use the same kilo/milli pattern!
2. Side-by-side conversions: mass and capacity follow the same rules.
3. Comparison problems: which is more, 2 kg or 1,500 g? 3 L or 3,200 mL?
4. Word problems mixing mass and capacity:
   - 'A recipe needs 500 g of flour and 250 mL of milk. If you double the recipe, how much of each?'
   - 'A bottle holds 2 L. You pour out 750 mL. How much is left?'
5. Connect to decimals: 1,500 g = 1.5 kg; 250 mL = 0.25 L.
6. Challenge: ordering items by mass or capacity from least to greatest.
materials_needed: Balance scale and measuring cups (for verification)

slides.setup_instructions: Create a reference chart showing the parallel structure: 1 km = 1000 m, 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 L = 1000 mL. Prepare word problems of increasing difficulty.

slides.text: 'Great news: mass and capacity conversions work EXACTLY like length conversions! 1 kg = 1,000 g, just like 1 km = 1,000 m. 1 L = 1,000 mL, same pattern. The metric system is beautifully consistent — everything is based on powers of 10.' Show the parallel conversion chart.

'Which is heavier: 2 kg or 1,500 g? Let us convert to the same unit. 2 kg = 2,000 g. Now compare: 2,000 g > 1,500 g. So 2 kg is heavier. Which holds more: 3 L or 3,200 mL? 3 L = 3,000 mL. 3,200 > 3,000, so 3,200 mL is more.' Practice comparing 3 more pairs.

'Word problem: A recipe needs 500 g of flour and 250 mL of milk. If you triple the recipe, how much of each? Flour: 500 x 3 = 1,500 g = 1.5 kg. Milk: 250 x 3 = 750 mL = 0.75 L. See how decimals help us express these conversions neatly?' Solve together.

slides.prompt: Solve: (1) 3 kg = ? g, (2) 4,500 g = ? kg, (3) 2 L = ? mL, (4) 750 mL = ? L, (5) Which is more: 1.5 kg or 1,200 g? (6) Which is more: 0.5 L or 600 mL? Word problems: A watermelon has a mass of 3.5 kg. You cut off a 900 g slice. How much is left (in kg)?

slides.text: The metric system makes conversions easy because the same pattern repeats: kilo means 1,000, milli means 1/1,000. Length (km, m, cm, mm), mass (kg, g, mg), and capacity (L, mL) all work the same way. You are now a metric measurement expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert between grams/kilograms and milliliters/liters and solve comparison word problems?

parent_notes: The parallel structure of metric units is the key insight: kilo always means 1,000 and milli always means 1/1,000, regardless of whether you are measuring length, mass, or capacity. Cooking is the best practice: recipes use grams and milliliters constantly. Let your child measure ingredients independently. The decimal connection (1,500 g = 1.5 kg) reinforces earlier decimal work.

title: Ancient Greece — Alexander the Great
description: Students learn about Alexander the Great: his education by Aristotle, his conquest of the Persian Empire, and how he spread Greek culture across a vast territory (Hellenistic period).
instructions:
1. Connect to philosophers: 'Remember Aristotle? His most famous student was not a philosopher but a king — Alexander of Macedonia!'
2. Alexander became king at age 20 after his father Philip II was assassinated.
3. He conquered the Persian Empire, Egypt, and lands as far as India — all by age 30!
4. He founded cities named Alexandria (the most famous in Egypt had the Great Library).
5. He spread Greek language, culture, and ideas everywhere he went — this is called Hellenization.
6. He died at only 32 — one of history's greatest 'what ifs.'
7. Show his empire on a map. Students trace the route of his conquests and label key cities.

slides.setup_instructions: Print a map showing Alexander's empire from Greece to India. Have the timeline updated with philosophers. Print blank outline maps of the same region.

slides.text: 'Aristotle's most famous student was not a philosopher — he was a CONQUEROR. His name was Alexander, and the world called him Alexander the GREAT. He was prince of Macedonia, a kingdom just north of Greece. His father, King Philip, hired Aristotle himself to tutor young Alexander. Imagine having one of the greatest minds in history as your personal teacher!'

'When Alexander became king at age 20, he set out to conquer the world — and he nearly did! He defeated the mighty Persian Empire, conquered Egypt (where he founded the city of ALEXANDRIA and its legendary Great Library), and pushed east all the way to INDIA! All of this before he turned 31. His empire stretched from Greece to the borders of China.'

'Wherever Alexander went, he brought Greek language, art, architecture, and ideas. This mixing of Greek culture with Eastern cultures is called HELLENIZATION — spreading all things Greek. Greek became the common language of trade and learning across a huge area. Sadly, Alexander died at only 32, possibly from disease. His empire was divided among his generals. But Greek culture remained!'

slides.prompt: On your outline map, trace Alexander's route of conquest from Macedonia through Turkey, Egypt, Persia, and to India. Label: Macedonia, Athens, Alexandria (Egypt), Babylon, Persepolis, and the Indus River. Color the extent of his empire. Write 3 sentences about why he is called 'the Great.'

slides.text: Alexander the Great conquered more territory in 11 years than anyone before him. But his greatest legacy was not military — it was cultural. By spreading Greek language and ideas across three continents, he created a shared culture that lasted for centuries and influenced everything that came after, including Rome.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Alexander's major achievements, trace his route of conquest, and explain Hellenization?

parent_notes: Alexander the Great is one of history's most fascinating figures. The fact that he accomplished so much so young captivates children. The connection to Aristotle shows how education shapes destiny. The Great Library of Alexandria is particularly exciting — it was an attempt to collect ALL human knowledge in one place. Discuss: what would a modern Library of Alexandria look like? (Perhaps the internet!) Alexander's story also leads naturally into the next civilization: Rome.

title: The Legacy of Greece — Greek Words in English
description: Students explore the extensive influence of Greek language on modern English. They learn common Greek roots, prefixes, and suffixes and use them to decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Review roots from last week: tele, graph, bio, geo, phon, scope.
2. Add new roots: auto (self), micro (small), mega (large/great), chrono (time), astro (star), hydro (water).
3. Add prefixes: anti- (against), mono- (one), poly- (many), hyper- (over/excessive).
4. Word building game: combine roots to make real words. Auto + graph = autograph (self-writing = signature!).
5. Decode unfamiliar words: chronometer (time measurer = clock), microscope (small viewer), polyglot (many tongues = speaks many languages).
6. Students create a Greek Root Dictionary: 10+ entries with root, meaning, and example words.
7. Challenge: can you figure out what 'autobiography' means using roots alone?

slides.setup_instructions: Make root word cards with the Greek root on one side and meaning on the other. Prepare blank booklets for the dictionary. Have a comprehensive root list available.

slides.text: 'Last week we learned some Greek roots: tele (far), graph (write), bio (life). Today we add more! AUTO means self — an automobile moves by itself! MICRO means small, MEGA means great. CHRONO means time — a chronometer measures time. ASTRO means star — an astronaut is a star sailor! HYDRO means water — a hydrant shoots water.'

'Now the magic: COMBINE roots to decode words you have never seen before! MICRO + SCOPE = microscope: a tool for seeing small things. TELE + SCOPE = telescope: a tool for seeing far things. AUTO + BIO + GRAPH + Y = autobiography: writing about your own life. You can figure out the meaning from the parts!'

'Let us try some hard ones: CHRONOLOGY = chrono (time) + logy (study of) = the study of time order. POLYTHEISM = poly (many) + theos (god) + ism = belief in many gods — that is what the Greeks had! DEMOCRACY = demos (people) + kratos (rule) = rule by the people!' Build on the board.

slides.prompt: Create your Greek Root Dictionary: write at least 10 entries. Each entry: the root, its Greek meaning, and 2-3 English words that use it. Then decode these challenge words using your roots: bibliography, monograph, hydrology, astronomical, antonym. Write what you think each means.

slides.text: Over 60% of English words have Greek or Latin roots. When you know the roots, you have a superpower: you can decode the meaning of words you have never seen before! Your Greek Root Dictionary is a tool you can keep adding to whenever you discover a new root. Greece's greatest gift may be its language.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use Greek roots to determine the meaning of unfamiliar English words?

parent_notes: Greek root knowledge is one of the highest-leverage vocabulary skills you can teach. It dramatically expands a child's ability to decode unfamiliar words in reading and on standardized tests. Make it a family game: when you encounter a difficult word, break it into roots and figure out the meaning together. The Greek Root Dictionary is a living document — keep adding to it! Over 60% of English words have Greek or Latin origins.

title: Read Aloud — Alexander the Great and His Horse Bucephalus
description: A read-aloud about the famous story of young Alexander taming the wild horse Bucephalus, exploring themes of courage, observation, and understanding animals.
instructions:
1. Introduction: 'Before Alexander conquered the world, he conquered a horse! This story shows us what made Alexander special.'
2. Read the tale: A wild horse that no one could ride. Young Alexander noticed the horse was afraid of its own shadow. He turned Bucephalus to face the sun, mounted him, and rode!
3. Discuss: What did Alexander see that no one else did? (The shadow was scaring the horse.)
4. Alexander used OBSERVATION (like a scientist) and COURAGE (like a hero).
5. Bucephalus became Alexander's loyal companion through all his conquests.
6. Students write: 'Alexander succeeded because he...' and draw the key scene.
7. Discuss: when has careful observation helped you solve a problem?

slides.setup_instructions: Select a version of the Bucephalus story appropriate for ages 6-9. Preview for dramatic read-aloud moments.

slides.text: 'Before Alexander conquered empires, he had to conquer a HORSE! When Alexander was just a boy, a horse trader brought a magnificent black stallion to King Philip. The horse was wild and no one could ride him. Everyone was ready to send the horse away. But young Alexander said: Wait! I can see what is wrong.'

Read the story with drama and suspense. 'Alexander noticed something no one else did — the horse was afraid of its OWN SHADOW! It kept seeing this dark shape moving on the ground. Alexander gently turned the horse to face the SUN, so its shadow was behind it. Then he stroked its mane, spoke softly, and mounted. The horse calmed. Alexander rode like the wind!'

After reading: 'What made Alexander special in this story? He OBSERVED carefully — he saw what others missed. He was BRAVE — he approached a wild horse that had thrown grown men. And he was COMPASSIONATE — he understood the horse's fear instead of using force. These are the qualities that later made him a great leader.'

slides.prompt: Draw the moment Alexander turns Bucephalus toward the sun. Show the shadow behind them. Below, write: 'Alexander succeeded because he...' Explain in at least 3 sentences what qualities he showed. Then answer: Can you think of a time when you noticed something others missed? Write about it.

slides.text: The Bucephalus story teaches us that observation and empathy are more powerful than force. Alexander did not overpower the horse — he understood it. Bucephalus carried Alexander faithfully for 20 years, through all his battles, all the way to India. When Bucephalus finally died, Alexander named a city after him. That is loyalty and love!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Bucephalus story and explain what qualities Alexander demonstrated?

parent_notes: The Bucephalus story is one of history's great character stories. It demonstrates that intelligence and empathy are more powerful than brute force — a deeply Montessori message. The lesson that careful observation can solve problems others cannot is applicable to science, math, and everyday life. After the story, ask your child: 'What problems could you solve by observing more carefully?'

title: Figurative Language — Writing with Figurative Language
description: Students apply all three types of figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification) in their own creative writing. They write a descriptive paragraph rich with figurative language.
instructions:
1. Review: simile (like/as), metaphor (is), personification (human qualities).
2. Read a professional paragraph that uses all three types. Identify each one.
3. Discuss the effect: figurative language makes writing vivid, emotional, and memorable.
4. Model writing a descriptive paragraph together, deliberately including all three types.
5. Topic options: a storm, a sunset, a bustling city, an ancient Greek battle, the ocean.
6. Students write a descriptive paragraph (6-8 sentences) including at least 1 simile, 1 metaphor, and 1 personification.
7. Peer review: identify each type in partner's writing.
materials_needed: Pencils and colored pencils for marking

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a model paragraph using all three types of figurative language. Have the reference chart displayed.

slides.text: 'You have learned to IDENTIFY figurative language. Now you will USE it in your own writing! The best writers use similes, metaphors, and personification naturally — they paint pictures with words. Today, we practice writing description that sings with figurative language.'

Model on the board: 'Let us describe a storm together. The sky was an angry bruise of purple and black (metaphor). Lightning cracked like a giant whip (simile). The wind screamed through the trees, tearing at branches with furious fingers (personification). See how each sentence paints a vivid picture? Your reader can SEE, HEAR, and FEEL the storm!'

'Your turn! Choose a topic: a storm, a sunset, the ocean, an ancient battle, or a peaceful forest. Write 6-8 sentences of rich description. You MUST include at least 1 simile, 1 metaphor, and 1 personification. After writing, go back and underline each one in a different color so we can see them clearly.'

slides.prompt: Write a descriptive paragraph (6-8 sentences) using all three types of figurative language. After writing, underline similes in yellow, metaphors in blue, and personification in green. Share with a partner or parent — can they identify each type?

slides.text: Your descriptive paragraphs are alive with figurative language! Similes, metaphors, and personification are the tools that transform ordinary writing into extraordinary writing. From now on, challenge yourself to include at least one piece of figurative language in everything you write.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a descriptive paragraph that effectively uses simile, metaphor, and personification?

parent_notes: This is the culmination of the figurative language unit — moving from identification to application. The color-coding system (yellow/blue/green for each type) makes the abstract concrete. Encourage your child to revise earlier pieces of writing by adding figurative language. This is a transferable skill: once children start using figurative language, their writing improves dramatically across all subjects.

title: Measurement — Mixed Word Problems: Length, Mass, and Capacity
description: Students solve word problems that require them to determine the correct type of measurement (length, mass, or capacity) and apply appropriate units and conversions.
instructions:
1. Review all three measurement types: length (m, cm, km), mass (g, kg), capacity (L, mL).
2. Key question: WHAT are you measuring? Distance/size = length. Heaviness = mass. Liquid amount = capacity.
3. Practice: 'What unit would you use to measure: the height of a tree? The amount of juice in a glass? The mass of a textbook?'
4. Multi-step word problems mixing all types:
   - 'Alexander's army marched 25 km per day. How many meters per day? How many km in a week?'
   - 'A Greek potter uses 2.5 kg of clay per pot. She has 10 kg. How many pots can she make?'
5. Students solve a varied set of 10 problems.
6. Create a measurement reference card with all units and conversions.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 10 word problems mixing length, mass, and capacity. Create a comprehensive reference chart showing all three measurement types and their conversions.

slides.text: 'You now know THREE types of metric measurement: LENGTH (how long, how far), MASS (how heavy), and CAPACITY (how much liquid). The first step in any measurement problem is deciding WHICH type you are measuring. Then choose the right unit and solve.' Practice categorizing 6 scenarios.

'Alexander's army marched 25 km per day. First: this is LENGTH — distance traveled. How many meters per day? 25 x 1,000 = 25,000 m. How far in a week (7 days)? 25 x 7 = 175 km. Could we convert? 175 km = 175,000 m!' Model the complete solution process.

'A Greek potter uses 2.5 kg of clay per pot. She has 10 kg total. How many pots? This is MASS. 10 divided by 2.5 = 4 pots. She has 0 kg left over. What if she had 11 kg? 11 / 2.5 = 4 pots with 1 kg left over (because 4 x 2.5 = 10, and 11 - 10 = 1).' Show division strategy.

slides.prompt: Solve 10 mixed measurement problems. For each: (1) decide the measurement type (length, mass, or capacity), (2) choose the correct unit, (3) solve, showing work. Then create a Measurement Reference Card on an index card: list all units, conversions, and one benchmark for each.

slides.text: You are now fluent in all three types of metric measurement! Remember: first decide WHAT you are measuring (distance, weight, or liquid), then choose the right unit, then solve. Your reference card is a handy tool to keep in your math folder.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student determine the correct measurement type for a situation and solve mixed word problems involving length, mass, and capacity?

parent_notes: Mixed problems are more challenging because students must first identify the type of measurement before solving. This real-world skill is important: nobody tells you 'this is a length problem' in daily life — you have to figure it out. The reference card is a useful study tool. Continue reinforcing measurement at home through cooking (mass/capacity) and home improvement projects (length).

title: Earth Science — Minerals and Their Properties
description: Students learn how to identify minerals using their properties: color, luster, hardness, streak, and crystal shape. They test real mineral samples using simple identification techniques.
instructions:
1. Review: rocks are made of minerals. Now let us study minerals themselves.
2. Mineral properties:
   - COLOR: what color is it? (least reliable — many minerals come in multiple colors)
   - LUSTER: how does it reflect light? (metallic, glassy, waxy, dull)
   - HARDNESS: how easily does it scratch? (Mohs scale: 1-10, talc to diamond)
   - STREAK: what color powder does it leave when rubbed on a tile?
   - CRYSTAL SHAPE: what geometric shape do its crystals form?
3. Test minerals: scratch test (fingernail = 2.5, penny = 3.5, nail = 5.5).
4. Streak test on a porcelain tile.
5. Students test and record properties of 5-6 mineral samples.
6. Try to identify each mineral using a key.
materials_needed: Mineral samples (quartz, feldspar, mica, calcite, pyrite, talc)

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a mineral testing station with samples, streak plate, penny, nail, and magnifying glass. Prepare recording charts with columns for each property.

slides.text: 'Rocks are made of MINERALS — natural, non-living substances with a specific chemical makeup. There are over 4,000 known minerals! To identify them, we test their PROPERTIES — observable characteristics. Today we become mineral detectives!'

'Five key properties: COLOR — what color is it? But be careful, some minerals come in many colors, so color alone is not enough. LUSTER — how does it reflect light? Metallic (like metal), glassy (like glass), waxy, or dull. HARDNESS — can you scratch it? The Mohs scale goes from 1 (talc, very soft) to 10 (diamond, hardest). Your fingernail is about 2.5.'

'STREAK — rub the mineral across this white tile. The powder left behind is the streak color, and it is MORE reliable than the mineral's surface color! CRYSTAL SHAPE — minerals form crystals with geometric shapes: cubes, hexagons, needles.' Demonstrate each test with one mineral. 'Now you test the rest like real geologists!'

slides.prompt: Test 5-6 mineral samples. For each, record: color, luster (metallic/glassy/waxy/dull), hardness (test with fingernail, penny, and nail), streak color, and any crystal shape you observe. Then use the identification key to try to name each mineral. How many can you identify?

slides.text: Scientists identify minerals by testing multiple properties — never just one! Color can be misleading, but hardness, streak, and luster together usually give a clear identification. You used the same techniques that real geologists use in the field. Every rock you see is a collection of minerals waiting to be identified!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student test and describe mineral properties (color, luster, hardness, streak) and use a key to identify common minerals?

parent_notes: Mineral testing is hands-on science at its best. Mineral kits with streak plates are available from educational suppliers. If you do not have samples, you can find common minerals outdoors: quartz is extremely common (clear or white, very hard), mica flakes apart in thin sheets, and calcite fizzes with vinegar. The Mohs hardness scale is a practical tool — diamond cutters and jewelers use it daily. Start a mineral collection!

title: Geometry — Angles: Right, Acute, and Obtuse
description: Students learn to identify and classify angles as right (90 degrees), acute (less than 90), or obtuse (greater than 90). They find angles in their environment and in geometric shapes.
instructions:
1. What is an angle? The space between two lines that meet at a point (vertex).
2. Demonstrate with two pencils or sticks: open and close them to show different angles.
3. RIGHT ANGLE: exactly 90 degrees, like the corner of a book or paper. Makes an L shape.
4. ACUTE ANGLE: less than 90 degrees. Smaller than a right angle. 'Acute' means sharp/small.
5. OBTUSE ANGLE: greater than 90 degrees. Wider than a right angle. 'Obtuse' means blunt/wide.
6. Use the corner of a paper as a right-angle tester: hold it against an angle to compare.
7. Angle hunt: find and classify 10 angles in the room.
8. Students draw and label examples of each type.
materials_needed: Two pencils or sticks for angle demonstration
Images of shapes with labeled angles

slides.setup_instructions: Cut out a right-angle tester from stiff cardboard. Have the protractor ready for demonstration (students will not use it yet). Prepare angle examples.

slides.text: 'An ANGLE is formed when two lines meet at a point. That point is called the VERTEX.' Hold two pencils together at one end and open them. 'See? As I open them wider, the angle gets bigger. Let us learn three types of angles.' Open and close slowly.

'A RIGHT ANGLE is exactly 90 degrees — like the corner of this piece of paper. See that perfect L shape? Right angles are everywhere: book corners, door frames, windows, tables.' Hold up paper corner. 'An ACUTE angle is SMALLER than 90 degrees — the opening is narrower, pointier. Think of a sharp blade — acute means sharp!'

'An OBTUSE angle is LARGER than 90 degrees — the opening is wider than a right angle. Think of a clock at 10:10 — those hands form an obtuse angle.' Demonstrate with pencils. 'To test: hold the corner of your paper against the angle. If it matches = right. If the angle is smaller = acute. If larger = obtuse.' Practice with 5 angles.

slides.prompt: Angle hunt: find 10 angles in your room. For each, classify it as right, acute, or obtuse. Record where you found it and what type. Then draw 3 examples of each type and label them. Challenge: what angles can you find in the letters of the alphabet?

slides.text: Right angles are 90 degrees (like paper corners). Acute angles are less than 90 (sharp and small). Obtuse angles are more than 90 (wide and blunt). The paper-corner test lets you classify any angle quickly. Angles are the building blocks of all geometry — from triangles to architecture!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and classify angles as right, acute, or obtuse using a right-angle reference?

parent_notes: Angles are fundamental to geometry and appear constantly in daily life. The paper-corner test is a simple, effective tool — have your child carry a small piece of cardboard to test angles around the house. Clock positions are great angle practice: 3:00 = right angle, 1:00 = acute, 10:00 = obtuse. The Greek connection: the word 'geometry' comes from Greek (geo = earth + metron = measure) — geometry was invented to measure land!

title: Rock Art — Creating Art from Natural Materials
description: Students create art using rocks, minerals, and natural materials, connecting to the earth science unit. They paint rocks, create rock mosaics, or build cairns (balanced rock stacks).
instructions:
1. Connect to science: 'This week we studied rocks and minerals. Today we turn them into ART!'
2. Show examples of rock art throughout history: cave paintings (pigments from minerals), mosaics, cairns, rock gardens.
3. Option A: Paint rocks with designs (mandalas, animals, patterns, Greek-inspired designs).
4. Option B: Create a rock mosaic — arrange small stones to form a picture or pattern.
5. Option C: Build a cairn (balanced rock stack) — this requires patience and understanding of balance.
6. Students choose their preferred project and create.
7. Discuss: how have humans used natural materials for art throughout history?

slides.setup_instructions: Collect smooth rocks (river rocks work best for painting). Cover workspace. Sort small pebbles by color for mosaics. Have all supplies organized by project option.

slides.text: 'Humans have been making art with rocks for over 40,000 years! Cave paintings were made with pigments ground from minerals. Ancient mosaics used small stones to create pictures. Japanese rock gardens arrange stones for meditation. Today, we continue this tradition by creating our own rock art!'

'You have three options: PAINTED ROCKS — use acrylic paint to create designs on smooth rocks (mandalas, animals, Greek patterns, or anything you wish). ROCK MOSAICS — arrange small colorful pebbles on cardboard to form a picture or pattern, then glue them down. Or CAIRNS — stack rocks in a balanced tower. Each requires different skills!'

Demonstrate briefly: For painted rocks: 'Paint a base coat first, let it dry, then add your design.' For mosaics: 'Arrange your stones FIRST without glue, adjust until you like the design, THEN glue.' For cairns: 'Find the balance point of each rock. Start with the largest and most stable at the bottom.' Let students choose and begin.

slides.prompt: Choose your rock art project and create it. Painted rock: create a beautiful design (consider Greek-inspired patterns like the Greek key). Mosaic: arrange stones to form a picture at least 6 inches across. Cairn: stack at least 5 rocks in a balanced tower. Take your time and enjoy working with natural materials!

slides.text: Rocks are some of the oldest materials on Earth, and humans have used them for art since the very beginning. Your rock art connects you to 40,000 years of creative tradition. Painted rocks make wonderful gifts — hide them in your neighborhood for others to find!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create art using natural rock materials and explain how humans have historically used rocks for artistic expression?

parent_notes: Rock painting has become a popular community activity — painted rocks are hidden in public places for others to find. This could be a fun family project. The mosaic option develops spatial planning skills, and cairn building develops patience and understanding of balance and gravity. All options connect art to the earth science unit. Save the best rock art as a portfolio piece.

title: Figurative Language Review — Identifying All Types in Context
description: Students review and practice identifying similes, metaphors, and personification in longer passages. They take a figurative language quiz and create a figurative language resource page.
instructions:
1. Rapid review: define simile, metaphor, personification with examples.
2. Read 2 passages aloud. Students identify all figurative language, classify by type, and interpret meaning.
3. Quiz: 15 sentences — identify each as simile, metaphor, personification, or literal.
4. Students create a Figurative Language Reference Page: definition, signal words, 3 examples for each type.
5. Bonus: find figurative language in their current independent reading book.
6. Celebrate: share favorite examples they have written this week.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the 15-question quiz. Select 2 review passages rich with figurative language. Have all week's work available for reference.

slides.text: Rapid review: 'SIMILE: comparison using like or as. Her eyes shone like diamonds. METAPHOR: direct comparison, no like or as. Her eyes were diamonds. PERSONIFICATION: giving human qualities to non-human things. The stars winked at us. All three paint pictures with words. All three make writing more powerful.'

Read a passage aloud. 'Now find EVERY piece of figurative language. Highlight similes in yellow, metaphors in blue, personification in green. For each one, explain what it really means. Remember: literal language means exactly what it says. Figurative language means something beyond the literal words.' Practice with passage 1 together.

'Now for your quiz: 15 sentences. For each one, decide if it is a simile, metaphor, personification, or LITERAL (not figurative at all). Read carefully — not every sentence is figurative!' Go over quiz expectations and let students work.

slides.prompt: Take the 15-question figurative language quiz. Then create a beautiful Figurative Language Reference Page in your journal: for each type (simile, metaphor, personification), write the definition, signal words, and 3 original examples. Decorate it — this is a page you will use again!

slides.text: You are now fluent in figurative language! You can identify similes, metaphors, and personification in anything you read, and you can use all three in your own writing. These tools will make you both a better reader and a better writer. Keep collecting favorites in your journal!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately identify and classify similes, metaphors, and personification in various contexts?

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates a major language arts skill. The reference page is a useful tool for future writing assignments. Figurative language appears on virtually every standardized reading test, so this is time well invested. Continue pointing out figurative language in daily life — advertisements, songs, and conversations are full of it. The ability to distinguish literal from figurative meaning is crucial for reading comprehension.

title: Measurement — Assessment and Real-World Application
description: Students complete a measurement assessment covering length, mass, and capacity, then apply their skills to a real-world measurement project: planning a recipe or designing a room layout.
instructions:
1. Assessment (15 minutes): 15 questions covering all measurement types.
   - Read and write metric measurements
   - Convert between units (cm/m, g/kg, mL/L)
   - Choose appropriate units
   - Solve word problems
2. After the assessment: real-world application project.
   - Option A: Follow a recipe — measure ingredients in grams and milliliters.
   - Option B: Design a room layout on grid paper — measure real furniture in cm, convert to scale.
3. Students work on their chosen project.
4. Reflect on measurement skills: what was easy? What was challenging?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the 15-question assessment. Have recipe ingredients OR grid paper and rulers ready for the application project.

slides.text: 'Today you show everything you have learned about measurement! First, a short assessment: 15 questions covering length, mass, and capacity. Take your time, read carefully, show your work, and check your answers. You know this material — trust your preparation!'

'After the assessment, we put measurement into ACTION! Choose a project: Option A — follow a real recipe and measure all ingredients using grams and milliliters. Option B — design a room layout. Measure real furniture in centimeters and draw it to scale on grid paper. Both projects show that measurement is a REAL skill you use in life!'

'For the recipe project: read the recipe first, gather ingredients, then measure each one carefully. For the room layout: measure length and width of furniture pieces, choose a scale (1 square = 10 cm), and draw the room and furniture on grid paper. Both require precision and planning!'

slides.prompt: Complete the 15-question assessment (15 minutes). Then choose your project: (A) follow a metric recipe, measuring precisely, or (B) measure and draw a room layout to scale. Document your work with measurements and observations.

slides.text: Measurement is one of the most practical skills in mathematics. Every day, people measure: cooks measure ingredients, builders measure materials, scientists measure specimens, doctors measure dosages. You now have a strong foundation in metric measurement that will serve you for life!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student demonstrate proficiency in all three types of metric measurement through both assessment and practical application?

parent_notes: The assessment helps identify any remaining gaps in measurement understanding. Review incorrect answers together to clarify misconceptions. The real-world projects are the true test — if your child can measure recipe ingredients accurately or create a room layout to scale, they truly understand measurement. Cooking with metric measurements is ongoing practice you can do weekly.

title: Europe — Rivers, Mountains, and Climate Zones
description: Students deepen their study of European geography by examining major physical features: the Alps, Pyrenees, Scandinavian Mountains, the Rhine, Danube, and Volga rivers, and Europe's varied climate zones.
instructions:
1. Review the map of Europe from Day 1.
2. Mountain ranges: Alps (central), Pyrenees (Spain/France border), Ural Mountains (Europe/Asia boundary), Scandinavian Mountains.
3. Major rivers: Rhine (Germany), Danube (longest in EU, flows through 10 countries!), Volga (longest in Europe, Russia), Thames (London).
4. Climate zones: Mediterranean (warm, dry summers), oceanic (mild, rainy), continental (cold winters, hot summers), Arctic (far north).
5. How climate affects lifestyle: Mediterranean = outdoor living, olive groves; Arctic = short growing season, fishing.
6. Students create a physical features map and a climate zone map of Europe.

slides.setup_instructions: Print 2 blank outline maps per student (one for physical features, one for climate zones). Display large reference maps of both types.

slides.text: 'Europe has dramatic physical features! The ALPS run through France, Switzerland, Italy, and Austria — they include Mont Blanc, the highest peak in Western Europe. The PYRENEES separate Spain from France. The URAL MOUNTAINS in Russia mark where Europe ends and Asia begins.' Trace each on the map.

'Europe's great rivers: the DANUBE flows through TEN countries — more than any other river in the world! It starts in Germany and ends at the Black Sea. The RHINE flows through Germany — it has been a major trade route for centuries. The VOLGA in Russia is the longest river in Europe.' Trace each river.

'Europe has very different climates! The MEDITERRANEAN region (southern Europe: Spain, Italy, Greece) has warm, dry summers — perfect for olives and grapes. Northern Europe has OCEANIC climate — mild but rainy. Eastern Europe has CONTINENTAL climate — cold winters and warm summers. And way up north, near the Arctic Circle, it is cold and dark in winter!'

slides.prompt: Map 1 — Physical Features: draw and label the Alps, Pyrenees, Ural Mountains, and Scandinavian Mountains. Trace and label the Danube, Rhine, Volga, and Thames rivers. Map 2 — Climate Zones: color-code four climate regions (Mediterranean, oceanic, continental, Arctic) and label each. Write one feature of daily life in each zone.

slides.text: Europe may be small, but its geography is incredibly diverse — from Mediterranean beaches to Arctic tundra, from the towering Alps to river plains. This geographic variety created enormous cultural diversity: different climates led to different foods, clothing, traditions, and ways of life. Geography truly shapes culture!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify major European mountain ranges, rivers, and climate zones and explain how climate affects lifestyle?

parent_notes: Physical geography and climate are interconnected — mountains create rain shadows, rivers enable trade, and climate determines agriculture. These connections are foundational to understanding why civilizations developed where and how they did. Compare European rivers to those studied in other civilizations (Nile, Tigris/Euphrates, Yellow River, Yangtze). A common thread emerges: great civilizations arise along great rivers.

title: European Cultures — Food, Language, and Traditions
description: Students explore the cultural diversity of Europe through its foods, languages, and traditions. They compare customs across several countries and discover connections between geography and culture.
instructions:
1. 'Europe has about 50 countries and over 200 languages! Let us explore this incredible diversity.'
2. Language families: Romance languages (French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese — from Latin/Rome!), Germanic (English, German, Dutch, Swedish), Slavic (Russian, Polish, Czech).
3. Foods that reflect geography: Mediterranean = olive oil, fish, wine. Northern = hearty soups, bread, cheese. Eastern = borscht, pierogies.
4. Traditions: Spanish flamenco, German Oktoberfest, French Bastille Day, Italian Carnival.
5. Students create a European Culture Mini-Book: 4 pages, each about a different country, with food, language, tradition, and flag.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare mini-books by folding paper. Gather reference materials on 6-8 European countries. Print or display flag images.

slides.text: 'Europe is a patchwork of cultures! Over 200 languages are spoken. Many European languages are related — like a family tree. French, Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese are all ROMANCE languages because they all came from LATIN, the language of ancient Rome (which we will study next week!). English and German are GERMANIC languages. Russian and Polish are SLAVIC languages.'

'European foods reflect geography and climate. In the warm Mediterranean south: olive oil, fresh fish, tomatoes, and pasta. In the cooler north: hearty bread, cheese, sausages, and potatoes. In Eastern Europe: borscht (beet soup), pierogies (dumplings), and dark rye bread. The land and climate shape what people eat!'

'Every country has unique traditions too! Spain has flamenco dancing and bull festivals. Germany has Oktoberfest. France celebrates Bastille Day with fireworks. Italy has Carnival with masks — like Greek theater! Sweden celebrates Midsummer with flower crowns. Despite their differences, Europeans also share values: art, education, good food, and centuries of intertwined history.'

slides.prompt: Create a European Culture Mini-Book with 4 pages. Choose 4 different countries. For each country, include: the flag (drawn in color), one traditional food, a greeting in the language, one cultural tradition, and one interesting fact. Decorate each page to reflect that country's character.

slides.text: Europe's cultural diversity is remarkable — so many languages, foods, and traditions in such a small continent! Yet there are also deep connections: shared history, borrowed words, traded recipes, and intertwined traditions. Next week, we visit the civilization that united much of Europe for the first time: ANCIENT ROME!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe cultural features (food, language, traditions) of at least 4 European countries?

parent_notes: Cultural exploration through food, language, and traditions makes geography personal and memorable. Consider a European food night this week — try a recipe from one of the countries your child studied. Learning basic greetings in different languages (bonjour, hola, ciao, guten tag) is fun and builds cultural awareness. The language family concept (Romance, Germanic, Slavic) introduces linguistics in an accessible way.

title: Read Aloud — Greek Myth: Persephone and the Seasons
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Persephone, explaining how the Greeks understood the changing seasons. Students explore how myths served as early science, explaining natural phenomena.
instructions:
1. Introduction: 'Why do we have seasons? Today we know about Earth's tilt. But how did the ancient Greeks explain it? With a myth!'
2. Read the myth: Persephone (daughter of Demeter, goddess of harvest) was taken to the underworld by Hades.
3. Demeter's grief caused all plants to die (winter). When Persephone returned for part of the year, Demeter was happy and plants grew (spring/summer).
4. But Persephone ate pomegranate seeds in the underworld, binding her to return for part of each year (fall/winter).
5. Discuss: myths as explanations for nature. What other natural events might myths explain?
6. Students write their own mini-myth explaining a natural event (why the sun rises, why it rains, etc.).
materials_needed: Greek mythology book with Persephone story

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate version of the Persephone myth. This is a sensitive story — ensure the version handles the abduction theme age-appropriately.

slides.text: 'Why do we have winter? Today, science tells us it is because the Earth tilts on its axis. But 2,500 years ago, the Greeks had a different explanation — a beautiful, sad story about a mother's love and a daughter's journey. This is the myth of PERSEPHONE and DEMETER.'

Read the myth. Build the emotional arc: Demeter's love for Persephone, the shock of her disappearance, Demeter's grief that causes all plants to wither and die (winter), the joy when Persephone returns (spring). Pause: 'Why do plants die in winter? Because Demeter is sad. Why do they bloom in spring? Because Demeter is happy!'

After reading: 'This myth is an explanation for a NATURAL EVENT — the seasons. Before science, every culture created stories to explain nature. Myths about why the sun rises, why the moon changes shape, why earthquakes happen. These are called ORIGIN MYTHS or ETIOLOGICAL MYTHS. Now, YOU will write your own!'

slides.prompt: Write your own mini-myth (one page) explaining a natural event. Choose: Why does the sun set? Why does it rain? Why do leaves change color? Why does thunder happen? Create characters (they can be gods, animals, or magical beings) and tell a story that explains the event. Illustrate your myth!

slides.text: The Persephone myth shows us that before science, humans used stories to make sense of the world. These myths are beautiful even though we now know the scientific explanations. Science tells us HOW nature works; myths help us FEEL our connection to nature. Both have value!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Persephone myth, explain how myths served as early explanations of nature, and write an original explanatory myth?

parent_notes: The Persephone myth is one of the most beloved Greek myths and an excellent example of how mythology and science intersect. The 'write your own myth' activity is wonderfully creative — children love inventing explanations for natural events. Keep these stories! They demonstrate both creative writing skills and understanding of how ancient peoples thought. Compare Greek origin myths to those from other cultures — many have similar themes.
